text:
not to call myself an -influencer-, ha, but I've been on the receiving side of campaigns using Peersway and it's been a good experience (if you're looking for really micro). I've also worked with a couple of PR firms for campaigns as well and that has gone well, so could be another option.

also, no personal experience with the platform, but I've heard both #paid and Fohr are pretty solid.

text: How has conference speaking changed for people since COVID? me + team is finding it much harder to identify open CFPs. Seems like a lot of places are rushing out virtual summits and primarily picking quickly from their personal network - not we’re seen a decreased opportunity for PR pitching or organic submissions.

elements.text: How has conference speaking changed for people since COVID? me + team is finding it much harder to identify open CFPs. Seems like a lot of places are rushing out virtual summits and primarily picking quickly from their personal network - not we’re seen a decreased opportunity for PR pitching or organic submissions.

text: The last rushed virtual conference I attended (ironically packed full of video conferencing vendors) was so bad. It put me off wanting to speak, for sure.

elements.text: The last rushed virtual conference I attended (ironically packed full of video conferencing vendors) was so bad. It put me off wanting to speak, for sure.

text: Hello everyone! What are the best practices for working with Guest Bloggers? Do you publish guest posts and if so, how do you determine which authors to publish on your branded blog and which ones to pass on? I want to make it a fair deal for both the guest blogger and the company, but I don't want to publish every pitch in my inbox.

elements.text: Hello everyone! What are the best practices for working with Guest Bloggers? Do you publish guest posts and if so, how do you determine which authors to publish on your branded blog and which ones to pass on? I want to make it a fair deal for both the guest blogger and the company, but I don't want to publish every pitch in my inbox.

text: Hi Kisha! Definitely make sure you have your guidelines posted so people can self-select whether they would be a good fit, and you have something to point to when you turn someone down. Include the types of articles and positions you'd like to see, length, and type of voice you are looking for (practitioners, researchers, writers who have published elsewhere, etc.) and ask to see other examples of their published work to make sure they are legit.

elements.text: Hi Kisha! Definitely make sure you have your guidelines posted so people can self-select whether they would be a good fit, and you have something to point to when you turn someone down. Include the types of articles and positions you'd like to see, length, and type of voice you are looking for (practitioners, researchers, writers who have published elsewhere, etc.) and ask to see other examples of their published work to make sure they are legit.

text: I only publish guest posts from authors at established, relevant brands that make sense for us to partner with from a brand perspective. Everyone else gets rejected with a polite “thanks but no thanks” email.

elements.text: I only publish guest posts from authors at established, relevant brands that make sense for us to partner with from a brand perspective. Everyone else gets rejected with a polite “thanks but no thanks” email.

text: Hey <@URAV154AV>, I understand that's a business policy, but with that process of accepting guest bloggers, how are you helping upcoming content marketers, say, like me two years ago?

elements.text: Hey
, I understand that's a business policy, but with that process of accepting guest bloggers, how are you helping upcoming content marketers, say, like me two years ago?

text: Thanks <@UUJBTH7RR>! Where do you post your guidelines? If you have an example, I would love to reference it to create some for my company.:pray:

! Where do you post your guidelines? If you have an example, I would love to reference it to create some for my company.

text: <@UUVRX9C13> I’m not. I don’t think guest blogs on my company’s blog are the way to do that. I run a meetup and community for content marketers, and I mentor and hire as many up and comers as I can, when I can.

elements.text: I’m not. I don’t think guest blogs on my company’s blog are the way to do that. I run a meetup and community for content marketers, and I mentor and hire as many up and comers as I can, when I can.

. What is appropriate to offer to the guest blogger in exchange for the content? Do you specify an agreement for sharing links to their twitter or bio?

text: <@UV5V2P0VB> not explicitly, no, but we usually have a call about the process, their pitch, etc. and they’ll offer to promote it on their company’s social channels. This is why, for me, partnering with only relevant guest contributors is so key. The link(s) included in their post have to be relevant to our audience, and ideally we’re attracting new people with the guest contributor’s/their company’s promotion.
